writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
Neal Caffrey leaned against the polished wooden counter, his eyes scanning the sleek, modern office as if searching for a way out. He had been working with the FBI for what felt like an eternity, using his exceptional skills to help them catch some of the most notorious art forgers in the business. It was a far cry from his past life, but he had made peace with it.

Or so he thought.

Across from him, FBI Agent Peter Burke sat with a file open on his lap, his expression a mix of curiosity and concern. "Neal, I need to ask you something," he said, his voice low and even.

Neal raised an eyebrow, sensing where this was going. "What is it, Pete?"

"I've been getting some... let's call them 'offers' from an old acquaintance of yours. He wants to get back into the game, and he thinks you're the perfect partner for the job."

Neal's gut twisted, his mind racing back to the days when he was the one proposing the heists, not the one being asked to join in. He had thought he'd left all that behind, but the temptation was still there, lingering just beneath the surface.

"What's the job?" he asked, trying to keep his tone neutral.

"A high-stakes art heist. A priceless painting, a state-of-the-art security system... it's the ultimate challenge."

Neal's eyes narrowed, his mind working overtime. This was the kind of job he used to live for, the kind of job that got his adrenaline pumping and his creative juices flowing. But something about it didn't feel right.

"It's a bad idea, Pete," he said finally, trying to sound convincing. "We've got too much to lose. If we get caught, I'm back to square one."

Peter leaned forward, his eyes locked on Neal's. "You're not just thinking about yourself, Neal. You're thinking about us, about the team. You're thinking about the life you've built here."

Neal felt a pang of guilt, knowing that Peter was right. He had come a long way since his days as a master art forger, and he had people who cared about him now. But the temptation was still there, whispering in his ear.

As he stood there, weighing his options, Neal couldn't shake the feeling that he was being pulled in two different directions. Part of him wanted to take the job, to prove to himself and everyone else that he was still the master forger he once was. But another part of him, the part that had grown and changed over the past few years, was screaming at him to stay away.

The door to the office opened, and Agent Diana Barrigan walked in, a look of concern on her face. "Neal, we need to talk about the Johnson case. We've got a lead on the forger's identity..."

Neal's eyes met Peter's, and he knew he had to make a decision. He took a deep breath, the words spilling out of him like a confession. "I'm not doing it, Pete. I'm not going back to that life. I'm done."

Peter's expression softened, a hint of a smile playing on his lips. "I knew you'd see it, Neal. You're not just a master forger; you're a consultant, a member of this team. And we need you."

As Neal nodded, feeling a weight lift off his shoulders, he knew that he had finally found what he was looking for – a sense of purpose, a sense of belonging. He was no longer the master art forger, but a man who had found a new path, a new life.

The heist was off, and Neal felt a sense of relief wash over him. He had changed, and he was determined to stay on the right path.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
Crowley stood at the edge of the crowded room, scanning the familiar faces as he made his way through the gathering. It had been years since he'd last seen Dean Winchester, and he'd almost forgotten the way his heart skipped a beat at the mere mention of the man's name.

Almost.

He'd built a new life since then, one that didn't involve getting tangled up in the affairs of a certain hunter. Or, rather, a certain hunter's brother. But as he spotted Dean across the room, a smile spread across his face, and he felt the old spark reignite.

It took him a few minutes to make his way through the crowd, but when he finally reached Dean's side, he felt a sense of familiarity wash over him. They exchanged a warm smile, and Crowley couldn't help but notice the way Dean's eyes crinkled at the corners as he smiled.

"Long time no see, Crowley," Dean said, his voice low and smooth.

"Indeed it has," Crowley replied, his own voice a little huskier than he'd intended. "I didn't know you were attending this gathering."

Dean shrugged. "I got roped into it by my family. They're always dragging me to these things."

Crowley raised an eyebrow. "And how do you feel about being dragged?"

Dean chuckled. "Let's just say I'm learning to appreciate the barbecue."

Crowley laughed, feeling a sense of ease wash over him that he hadn't experienced in years. "I'm sure it's a real treat."

As they chatted, Crowley found himself getting lost in Dean's eyes, remembering the way they'd used to talk, the way they'd used to laugh together. It was like no time had passed at all, and yet, everything had changed.

They talked for a while longer, catching up on old times, and Crowley couldn't help but feel a sense of wonder at how easily they'd fallen back into their old rhythm. It was like they'd never been apart at all.

But as the night wore on, Crowley started to feel a sense of restlessness, a sense that he was playing with fire by being around Dean again. He'd built a new life, one that didn't involve getting tangled up in the affairs of hunters and federal agents.

And yet, as he looked at Dean, he couldn't help but feel drawn to him, like a moth to a flame.

They exchanged a few more words, and then Dean leaned in, his voice low and husky. "Want to take a walk with me, Crowley?"

Crowley's heart skipped a beat as he nodded, feeling a sense of trepidation mixed with excitement. What was he getting himself into?

As they walked through the quiet streets, Crowley felt a sense of ease wash over him, like he'd finally found his way back home. They talked about everything and nothing, their conversation flowing easily, like they'd never been apart at all.

And then, without warning, Dean reached out and kissed him, the touch sending shivers down Crowley's spine. It was a soft, gentle kiss, but it sent a spark of electricity through him, making him feel alive in a way he hadn't felt in years.

As they pulled back, Crowley's heart was racing, his mind reeling with the implications of what had just happened. He'd never meant to fall for Dean again, but here he was, feeling like he was drowning in a sea of emotions.

"What are we doing, Dean?" Crowley asked, his voice barely above a whisper.

Dean smiled, his eyes crinkling at the corners. "I'm not sure, Crowley. But I think we're rewriting the plan."

Crowley's heart skipped a beat as he looked at Dean, feeling a sense of wonder at the possibilities that lay ahead. Some things, it seemed, were worth rewriting the plan for.

As they stood there, wrapped in each other's arms, Crowley knew that he was in trouble. He was falling for Dean all over again, and this time, he wasn't sure if he'd ever be able to let him go.

The federal agents would have to wait, at least for now. Crowley had more pressing matters on his mind – like figuring out how to navigate this new, tangled life he was building with Dean.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
Neal Caffrey leaned back in his chair, hands clasped together as he watched Agent Peter Burke pace back and forth in front of the whiteboard, markers scribbled on his hand. They were discussing the latest case, a complex scheme involving counterfeiting and money laundering, and Neal was trying to keep a straight face as Agent Burke lectured him on the importance of following procedure.

"You see, Neal, the key to solving this case is to follow every lead, no matter how small," Agent Burke said, his voice rising in excitement. "We can't just rush in and start making assumptions. We need to dot our i's and cross our t's."

Neal rolled his eyes, trying to keep a smirk from spreading across his face. "Oh, come on, Agent Burke. You're not going to lecture me on the importance of following procedure again, are you?"

Agent Burke stopped pacing and turned to face him, a stern expression on his face. "Actually, I am. You're a con artist, Neal. You're used to thinking on your feet and making things up as you go along. But this isn't a game. This is the FBI. We have rules and procedures for a reason."

Neal shrugged, trying to appear nonchalant. "I know, I know. But sometimes, Agent Burke, the rules get in the way of actually solving the case. Can't we just think outside the box for once?"

Agent Burke's expression turned incredulous. "Think outside the box? Neal, you're the one who's always getting us into trouble with your harebrained schemes and disregard for procedure. I'm surprised you're not advocating for a more relaxed approach to law enforcement."

Neal chuckled, a mischievous glint in his eye. "Hey, I'm just trying to keep things interesting, Agent Burke."

But as he watched Agent Burke continue to lecture him, something unexpected happened. He found himself getting defensive. Not because he disagreed with Agent Burke's approach, but because he realized that the man was right. For once, he was actually on the right side of the law, and it felt...good.

As the discussion continued, Neal found himself arguing in favor of following procedure, using Agent Burke's own logic against him. He pointed out the importance of gathering evidence and following due process, and to his surprise, Agent Burke was impressed.

"I'll be," Agent Burke said, a smile spreading across his face. "You're actually defending me, Neal."

Neal grinned, feeling a sense of pride he hadn't felt in a long time. "Hey, I'm just trying to do the right thing for once."

The rest of the discussion was a blur as Neal and Agent Burke worked together to crack the case. They spent hours pouring over evidence and interviewing witnesses, following every lead to its logical conclusion. And when they finally apprehended the perpetrators, Neal felt a sense of satisfaction he hadn't felt in years.

As they left the FBI office, Agent Burke turned to him with a grin. "You know, Neal, I never thought I'd say this, but I'm actually starting to enjoy working with you."

Neal chuckled, feeling a sense of camaraderie he hadn't felt before. "I'm glad to hear that, Agent Burke. I think we make a pretty good team."

And for once, Neal meant it.

Over the next few days, Neal found himself becoming more and more comfortable with the FBI's procedures. He began to see the value in following rules and regulations, and he even started to enjoy the sense of order and structure that came with it.

Agent Burke noticed the change in him, and he made sure to tease him about it every chance he got. "Hey, Neal, I see you're actually following procedure now. Who would have thought?"

Neal rolled his eyes, smiling. "Shut up, Agent Burke. I'm just trying to do the right thing."

But deep down, Neal knew that he was more than just trying to do the right thing. He was trying to find a new sense of purpose, a new way of living that didn't involve scamming and scheming. And with Agent Burke's help, he was starting to find it.

As they walked out of the FBI office one day, Agent Burke turned to him with a serious expression. "Neal, I have to say, I'm impressed. You're really coming around to the whole following procedure thing."

Neal grinned, feeling a sense of pride. "Hey, I'm a quick learner, Agent Burke. And I have to say, I'm actually starting to enjoy it."

Agent Burke chuckled, clapping him on the back. "I knew you had it in you, Neal. Now let's go get some coffee and celebrate."

Neal smiled, feeling a sense of belonging he hadn't felt in years. He was finally starting to find his place in the world, and it was all thanks to Agent Burke and the FBI.

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
"Captain, I'm telling you, we've checked every system, every wire, every connection. We're running out of time here," Chief Engineer Montgomery Scott said, his Scottish brogue thick with frustration.

Captain James T. Kirk's eyes narrowed as he studied the data streaming in on the viewscreen. "Bones, can you give me a reading on the ship's power reserves?"

Dr. Leonard "Bones" McCoy's face creased in concern. "We're down to 30% of our normal capacity, Jim. If we don't find the problem soon, we'll be dead in space for good."

Montgomery Scott let out a low growl. "I know that, sir. But I've run diagnostics on every system. We're not getting any readings on the engines, the propulsion systems, or even the life support. It's as if the ship itself is...dead."

Kirk's eyes flicked to the engineer, his expression thoughtful. "Montgomery, what do you make of it?"

The engineer hesitated, his brow furrowed. "I've been thinking, sir. Maybe it's not just a malfunction. Maybe it's...intentional."

The captain's eyes snapped to his engineer. "Intentional? What do you mean?"

Scott took a deep breath. "I mean, sir, maybe someone – or something – has deliberately shut down the ship's systems. Maybe it's not a technical failure after all."

Bones snorted. "That's a wild goose chase, Montgomery. We've got no evidence of sabotage."

Kirk's eyes never left Scott's face. "I want you to keep investigating, Montgomery. I want to know what's going on here. And I want answers – now."

As the clock ticked down, Montgomery Scott worked tirelessly to uncover the truth behind the ship's failure. He pored over schematics, ran diagnostics, and consulted with the crew. But with each passing hour, his theories grew more and more tenuous.

It wasn't until he stumbled upon an old maintenance log that the pieces began to fall into place. A minor repair job, a seemingly innocuous patch job on the ship's hull. But something about it nagged at him.

"Captain, I think I've found something," Scott called out, his voice low and urgent.

Kirk appeared at his side, his eyes scanning the viewscreen. "What is it, Montgomery?"

Scott's face was grim. "It's not a malfunction, sir. It's a...a safety feature. A failsafe designed to shut down the ship's systems in case of catastrophic failure."

Kirk's eyes narrowed. "And what's the trigger for this failsafe?"

Scott's voice was barely above a whisper. "The hull patch job. It was designed to seal off a compartment, but in the process, it triggered the failsafe."

Bones' voice cut in, his tone incredulous. "You mean to tell me that someone deliberately sealed off a compartment, knowing it would shut down the ship?"

Kirk's face was a mask of calm, but his eyes betrayed his anger. "Find out who did it, Montgomery. I want names."

As the crew scrambled to investigate, Montgomery Scott felt a sense of pride and satisfaction wash over him. He had uncovered the truth behind the ship's failure, and in doing so, had saved the crew from certain disaster.

But as he looked up at the captain, he saw something there that gave him pause. A glimmer of respect, perhaps, or maybe even something more.

"Montgomery," Kirk said, his voice low and even. "You've done it again. You've saved us all."

Scott's face went hot, but he knew he had earned it. He had proven himself, not just as an engineer, but as a member of the crew.

As the clock ticked down, Montgomery Scott knew that he had found something far more valuable than just a solution to the ship's failure. He had found a sense of belonging, of purpose. And he knew that no matter what challenges lay ahead, he would face them head-on, as a member of the USS Enterprise crew.

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
Neal Caffrey stood outside the FBI's New York office, the morning sunlight glinting off the glass façade as he watched Peter Burke, his handler, stride out to greet him. Their partnership had been a whirlwind of high-stakes cases and clever schemes, but this morning, Neal felt a growing sense of unease. Peter's expression was grim, and he didn't need to say a word for Neal to know that something was wrong.

"Good morning, Peter," Neal said, flashing his famous smile as he fell into step beside him.

"Neal, we have a problem," Peter said, his tone serious. "Agent Matthews from the FBI's Internal Affairs division is here to audit our team. And he's not just looking for minor discrepancies."

Neal's instincts kicked in, and he immediately went on high alert. "What's the issue?"

"We're not entirely sure, but Matthews seems to think one of our agents is involved in a high-profile forgery case. And, unfortunately, he's got his sights set on you."

Neal's eyes narrowed. "Me? Why me?"

Peter hesitated. "Because you're the one who's been...associated with some of the suspects in the case. And let's face it, Neal, you do have a bit of a reputation for, shall we say, bending the rules."

Neal's face fell, and he felt a familiar surge of frustration. "Peter, I didn't do it. I swear it. I would never forge anything, especially not something that could put our entire team in jeopardy."

Peter's expression softened, but Neal could see the doubt lingering in his eyes. "I know that, Neal. But Matthews is a tough nut to crack. And if he finds even a shred of evidence linking you to the forgery, it could be disastrous for both of us."

Neal's mind was already racing with possibilities. He knew he had to clear his name, but he also knew that he couldn't do it alone. He needed a plan, and he needed it fast.

As they stepped into the office, Neal spotted Agent Matthews standing by the coffee machine, his eyes scanning the room with a mixture of disdain and suspicion. Neal's instincts told him to keep his distance, but he knew he had to play it cool.

"Agent Matthews," Peter said, extending a hand. "Welcome to the team. I'm Agent Burke, Neal's handler."

Matthews' handshake was firm, but his eyes lingered on Neal for a beat too long. "Agent Burke. I'll be auditing your team's activities over the next few weeks. And I have to say, I'm not impressed with what I've seen so far."

Neal forced a laugh, trying to defuse the tension. "Well, Agent Matthews, we're always happy to have a fresh set of eyes looking over our shoulders. What can we do for you?"

Matthews' gaze narrowed. "I want to see all of your files, Agent Caffrey. Every single one. And I want to know why you've been associating with some of the suspects in the forgery case."

Neal's heart sank, but he knew he couldn't let his emotions get the better of him. He smiled, a plan already forming in his mind.

"Of course, Agent Matthews. I'd be happy to cooperate. But first, let me just grab my files from my office. I'll be right back."

As Neal walked away, he couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement. He knew he was taking a risk, but he also knew that he had to clear his name. And if that meant playing a little fast and loose with the rules, so be it.

The question was, would it be enough?
